title: 110_hr1568
content: The "Henry Ford Scholarship Program Act" authorizes the establishment of a program to award scholarships to high-achieving students graduating from secondary school after May 1, 2007, to pursue undergraduate degrees in specific fields at higher education institutions. Recipients of the scholarships will be known as "Henry Ford Scholars." The "Henry Ford Scholarship Program Act" sets a maximum scholarship amount of $5,000 per academic year and $20,000 in total. Scholarships are awarded for one academic year and can be renewed for up to four years. If funds are insufficient, scholarship amounts will be reduced proportionately. The "Henry Ford Scholarship Program Act" provides scholarships up to $5,000 per academic year and $20,000 in total, renewable for up to four years. Scholarships do not affect Federal grant assistance under the Higher Education Act, but total student financial aid cannot exceed the cost of attendance. Failure to obtain a degree in specified fields requires repayment of a portion of the scholarship. The Act requires repayment of scholarship awards received, plus interest at a rate not higher than that of loans under the Higher Education Act. Forgiveness is granted if the individual dies or becomes permanently disabled. Eligibility for the scholarship program is outlined in Section 4. Eligibility for the scholarship program under this Act requires the student to be a U.S. citizen, have a total adjusted gross income below specified thresholds based on dependency status, and be a graduate of a secondary school. To be eligible for the scholarship program, a student must be a U.S. citizen with a total adjusted gross income below specified thresholds, graduate from a secondary school, enroll in a bachelor's program in mathematics, science, engineering, or a health-related field, and have a cumulative GPA of at least 3.5. To maintain eligibility for the scholarship, a student must meet the GPA requirement and be enrolled in the second, third, or fourth year of undergraduate education. SEC. 5. SELECTION. Eligible students must submit an application for a scholarship under this Act to the Secretary. Scholarships are awarded on a first-come, first-served basis, with priority given to students who received a scholarship in the previous academic year. SEC. 6. REGULATIONS. The Secretary can create necessary regulations for this Act. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for fiscal year 2008 and subsequent years are authorized for this Act.
